wikipedia_page.main: The "Baroness de Calabrella" (c. 1788 – 6 October 1856, Paris) was an English socialite, journalist, and writer.

response: * Catherine Ball, known as the Baroness de Calabrella (c. 1788–1856), British writer and newspaper owner

Hughes' older sister Catherine Ball was a socialite, journalist, and novelist who eventually styled herself the "Baroness de Calabrella" after acquiring property in Italy.Catherine Ball Hughes at Victorian Research She married an older man, the Rev. Francis Lee, at the age of 16 in 1804, without her mother's permission, and was separated from him in 1810 on charges of adultery; her lover, Captain George de Blaquiere, was successfully sued by Lee for criminal conversation.The Sporting Magazine, Volume 36 (1810), p. 128-132 She was later a friend of the Countess of Blessington and married the Countess' first patron, Thomas Jenkins. Another sister, Ruth, married Houlton Hartwell, son of Admiral Francis Hartwell, in 1812; he was one of the Prince Regent's chaplains.Dod's peerage, baronetage and knightage, of Great Britain and Ireland..., 1865, entry "Hartwell", p. 313Debrett's Baronetage of England, ed. William Courthope, London, 1839, p. 318-9 A third sister, Sydney, married Sir John Ignatius Burke, 10th Baronet of Glinsk.genealogy from Peerage.com showing marriageThe Peerage Baronetage and Knightage of Great Britain and Ireland..., Charles L. Dodd, London, 1844, p. 55 There was a fourth sister, Elizabeth Ball. Despite the similarity in names and dates, the sculptor Robert Ball Hughes is unrelated.
